content.webTitle: Tottenham’s manager Pochettino tips his hat to ‘hard-working’ chairman Levy

fields.headline: Tottenham’s manager Pochettino tips his hat to ‘hard-working’ chairman Levy
fields.bodyText: Mauricio Pochettino has told Tottenham fans that Daniel Levy deserves “fantastic recognition” for the club’s new stadium rather than being made a scapegoat for the delays, as he talked up the chairman’s other side and how badly he was suffering. Spurs hope to be playing in the ground by early February, although the timings look tight. They confirmed the latest delay on Wednesday when they said the Manchester United game scheduled for 13 January will be played at Wembley, their temporary home. Pochettino was in cocksure and mischievous mood, buoyed by Tuesday’s Champions League last-16 qualification with the 1-1 draw at Barcelona and the knowledge he is coveted property. There is an awareness at Spurs that they face a fight to keep Pochettino next summer, with Real Madrid and United most prominent among his admirers. Pochettino knows it, he knows that Levy knows it and he teased him over it. But what he most wanted to get across was his admiration for how the chairman is driving the stadium project. “The chairman is so tired – the last few months, he didn’t sleep,” Pochettino said. “People don’t realise the magnitude of the project. It doesn’t just depend on him. I think it’s more than 20 companies that are working there. It’s why he needs to feel the love from the fans and the club. He is working so hard – too hard – to leave a legacy forever.” Pochettino described Levy as “not an easy man” but one who wants to “create things” for others. “He built the player lodge at the training ground, for example – it’s a five-star boutique hotel,” the manager added. “I asked him when he is going to sleep there and he said: ‘No, not for me. That’s for you and the players.’” The manager could not resist a series of jokes at Levy’s expense either, stating how the chairman is normally the first person to be blamed for the team’s defeats, which is “sometimes deserved”. Pochettino was asked whether he and Levy laughed about the managerial links to Real and United. “No, he doesn’t laugh,” the manager said, with a smile. “I don’t get bored [about reading them] but he is maybe worried. It’s not nice for Daniel to hear all that history. Should he be worried? No – [it’s] because he’s a worry man. That is different. He suffers. Because he’s jealous about me. He’s a very jealous person. Because of the rumours, eh?” The manager’s flippant tone illustrated both the depth of his relationship with Levy and his position of strength at the club. He was also asked whether he needed to reassure Levy about his long-term commitment.“No,” he replied. “It’s like when the sporting director or the president appears to say: ‘We trust in the manager.’ And the next game – lose and he is out. If you reassure [over] something, it’s because you are thinking in different [ways].”
